{
 "cells": [
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "20323ed6",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "# Creating Multiscale Images\n",
    "Sometimes it is useful or necessary to study processes across multiple scales.  It is possible to generate artificial images with 2 scales of porosity fairly easily.  "
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 1,
   "id": "9c674211",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "import porespy as ps\n",
    "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "1105142f",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Using ``blobs`` of different ``blobiness``\n",
    "Start by creating one image at a large scale.  Let's use blobs to define the large scale 'super-structure':"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 2,
   "id": "74716ab8",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 600x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "im1 = ps.generators.blobs([500, 500], blobiness=0.5, porosity=0.6)\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=[6, 6])\n",
    "ax.imshow(im1, interpolation='none')\n",
    "ax.axis(False);"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "ff9b7dc8",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Now we'll can create a second image of ``blobs``, but with a different scale.  These will represent the 'sub-structure':\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 3,
   "id": "c82dfd8f",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 600x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "im2 = ps.generators.blobs([500, 500], blobiness=2.5, porosity=0.5)\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=[6, 6])\n",
    "ax.imshow(im2, interpolation='none')\n",
    "ax.axis(False);"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "39bd448e",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Finally, we can multiply these two image (i.e. arrays) together, which will have the effect of perforating the foreground phase of ``im1`` with holes defined by the background phase of ``im2``.  Note the inverting of the image to ensure the foreground and background are maintained:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 4,
   "id": "5a8f9e30",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 600x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "im3 = ~(~im1*im2)\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=[6, 6])\n",
    "ax.imshow(im3, interpolation='none')\n",
    "ax.axis(False);"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "70fdab1e",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "The pore sizes can be analyzed using ``local_thickess``, to confirm a bi-modal pore size distribution:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 5,
   "id": "74eda829",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "application/vnd.jupyter.widget-view+json": {
       "model_id": "85e7d8da35c1478f9806d705fe1deb96",
       "version_major": 2,
       "version_minor": 0
      },
      "text/plain": [
       "  0%|          | 0/25 [00:00<?, ?it/s]"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "lt = ps.filters.local_thickness(im3)\n",
    "psd = ps.metrics.pore_size_distribution(lt)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 6,
   "id": "0ee7b1f2",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 640x480 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "ps.visualization.bar(psd);"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "549d8721",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Using ``random_spheres`` to insert non-overlapping spheres into ``blobs``\n",
    "Another way is to use ``random_spheres`` to insert spheres into the foreground of another image.  Let's use ``blobs`` to define the superstructure, the perforate it with holes. Note that we invert the image (`~`) before passing it to `random_spheres` so that the holes are added to the solid phase, then the result is inverted back."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 10,
   "id": "9b90b032",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 600x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "im1 = ps.generators.blobs([300, 300], blobiness=0.5, porosity=0.6)\n",
    "im2 = ~ps.generators.random_spheres(im=~im1, r=10, clearance=-2)\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=[6, 6])\n",
    "ax.imshow(im2, interpolation='none')\n",
    "ax.axis(False);"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "38a8a570",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Summary\n",
    "The concept of generate multiple images and different scales then superimposing them is a very easy to make some simple multiscale images for prototyping and testing workflows that require multiscale images.  "
   ]
  }
 ],
